stream_context.summary: Kaze began by detailing his complete rewrite of the Mario 64 sound engine, then spent the majority of the stream working on the game's large overworld. He focused on refining the 3D layout, tackling scale issues, and implementing a complex multi-texture technique to improve the visual quality of the sand and cliffs.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has completely rewritten the Mario 64 sound engine, resulting in significant performance gains and expanding musical capabilities from 16 to 32 simultaneous notes.
development_findings.quote: The sound engine is now around 80% faster than vanilla sound engine. The code is around a quarter of the size. We need much less memory. And we support 32 notes instead of 16.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is planned to be a massive level containing around 30 stars, featuring multiple distinct areas that will have their own dynamically fading musical themes.
Kaze has developed a new random number generation (RNG) system for the game that uses real-world entropy, mentioning a 'temperature thing' as a source.
development_findings.quote: The video is about, like, finding a new RNG algorithm that uses real-world entropy as well.

development_findings.summary: The next public release of the project will be the full game, as Kaze stated there will not be another demo.

Kaze implemented a complex multi-texture combiner to overcome the N64's color limitations, allowing for highly detailed textures like sand by mathematically rescaling the color range and using vertex colors for artistic control.
development_findings.quote: The detail is all there now. This way, instead of like a lot of coarseness on the small range, we have the coarseness on a much, much bigger range.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of the HackaMari64 decompilation project, citing their 'weird decisions,' failure to implement optimizations, and complaints about his code as reasons for his negative view.
development_findings.quote: I became a hater over time because they kept making really weird decisions. And then they kept complaining that they can't have my code because my code is too difficult to understand or debug or something, which I think made no sense.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a sound bug from the demo where sounds would cut out, tracing it to the Goomba bunnies jumping, and is actively working on fixing it with his new sound engine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that accomplishing large personal projects is possible for most people if they stop wasting their free time, reflecting a disciplined and focused work ethic.
context_findings.quote: If you think about your day-to-day, I'm sure you'll find that you waste most of your free time. And that's why you don't have time to do stuff like this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze wants to innovate on the traditional post-game experience by having the world permanently reflect the player's victory, rather than resetting to a pre-final boss state.
context_findings.quote: I want the player to save the world and then be like, yep, this is the world now. You saved it. Look at that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is highly conscious of Nintendo's legal actions and plans to strategically time the game's release and announcements to avoid their attention.
context_findings.quote: I can't release this around the same time as Nintendo releases anything. And I also can't announce a release date around the same time Nintendo releases anything. Because if I do they will literally kill me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a future 'legal' version of the game, which would require replacing all of Nintendo's original assets, but this is not an immediate priority.
context_findings.quote: If I want this to all be legal, I would technically need custom textures for everything. But that's something for later.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels his online fame restricts his freedom of expression on popular platforms, leading him to use less conventional outlets like LinkedIn to share his unfiltered thoughts.
context_findings.quote: I used twitter back when just to like post whatever the fuck was on my mind... and then my twitter got so famous that I'm no longer feeling comfortable to do so... so I switched to posting insane shit on linkedin.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep skepticism towards official narratives and history as taught by institutions, believing they are often manipulated by those in power.
context_findings.quote: History is always written by the winner. If I read anything in history I automatically do not really believe it... anytime there is people in power that have an interest in rewriting history they are going to rewrite history.

context_findings.summary: When asked about his long-distance relationship and move to Canada for Zeina, Kaze describes himself as 'completely reckless,' making major life decisions based on feeling without overthinking.

biobak.summary: Biobak is creating many of the game's custom textures, a crucial step for the project's unique visual identity and for a potential future 'legal' release.
Biobak provided Kaze with a Blender plugin for UV mapping, indicating he supports the team with tools and technical art resources beyond just creating assets.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions being married to Zeina and discusses their history, from meeting online to him moving to Canada, highlighting the intersection of their personal and professional lives.
Kaze mentions sending a message to 'Zane's DMs' during the stream, indicating their constant communication during development.

key_stories.title: Sound Engine Overhaul
key_stories.summary: To overcome the limitations of the original game, Kaze completely rewrote the Mario 64 sound engine. This intensive effort resulted in a faster, more efficient engine that doubles the number of concurrent notes, allowing for much richer music.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 sound engine was inefficient, buggy when adding new sounds, and limited composers to only 16 simultaneous notes.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a full week rewriting the entire sound engine from the ground up, optimizing the code and expanding its core features.
key_stories.outcome: A new, custom sound engine was created that is vastly more performant and doubles the note polyphony, enabling more complex and layered musical scores for the game. It is also expected to solve longstanding bugs.
key_stories.key_quote: The sound engine is now around 80% faster than vanilla sound engine. The code is around a quarter of the size. We need much less memory. And we support 32 notes instead of 16.

key_stories.title: Solving the Sand Texture Problem
key_stories.summary: When faced with the N64's texture format limitations making sand look flat, Kaze developed a sophisticated technical art solution. He created a custom material that combines multiple textures and uses vertex colors to add detailed, controllable graininess, overcoming the hardware's constraints.
key_stories.challenge: A large, detailed sand texture appeared flat and lacked detail due to the N64's limited 4-bit (I4) texture format, which causes visible color banding.
key_stories.process: Instead of using one texture, Kaze created a custom material 'combiner'. This uses one texture for color and a second for fine detail. By manipulating the combiner's math, he rescaled the color range of the detail texture, preserving its fidelity. He then used vertex colors on the 3D model to control the intensity of this detail effect.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a visually complex and detailed sand effect that appears high-resolution. He can also artistically control its graininess in different areas of the level, making some parts smooth and others coarse.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem is not the color curve, the problem is that I4 has very coarse colors and if you look at something like this, all this detail is going to be lost to quantization.

key_stories.title: Refining the Overworld Layout
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled with the overworld's scale, finding it too vast and empty. He addressed this by live-editing the level geometry, scaling down entire sections and adding large mountains to create better separation between zones and improve the overall layout.
key_stories.challenge: The main overworld area felt too large, open, and empty, making traversal uninteresting and failing to properly separate distinct themed zones like the Yoshi Village and a Bowser area.
key_stories.process: During the stream, Kaze experimented with the overworld layout in Blender. He scaled the entire area down by 20%, added large mountain geometry to act as dividers, and repositioned key landmarks to improve the flow and visual composition.
key_stories.outcome: Through iterative changes, Kaze arrived at a more reasonable scale for the overworld. The areas feel more distinct and the sightlines are broken up, creating a more interesting and believable space, though it remains a work in progress.
key_stories.key_quote: This still feels big and flat. I guess this is a little Yoshi mountain village and the Yoshis have two villages on this island.
